newsitem.title: USA: Fannie Mae says $2.80/shr '97 EPS plausible.
newsitem.headline: Fannie Mae says $2.80/shr '97 EPS plausible.

text.p: Wall Street's consensus estimates that Federal National Mortgage Association will earn $2.47 per share this year and $2.80 in 1997 are "within the range of plausibility," Fannie Mae Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer Timothy Howard said
Howard spoke to a reporter about the earnings projections after Fannie Mae executives spoke to the New York Society of Security Analysts.
He declined to comment on one estimate of $3.25 per share earnings for 1998, saying it was too far into the future.

On October 10 Fannie Mae reported third-quarter earnings of $0.63 per share, which brought earnings for the first nine months of the year to $1.83 per share. That compared to $0.54 in the third quarter of 1995 and $1.58 for the first nine months of 1995.
Fannie Mae Chairman and Chief Executive James Johnson told the meeting with analysts that U.S. mortgage originations are projected to fall to $650-$700 billion in 1997.
Fannie Mae economists expect originations this year to be about $775 billion. A drop to the midpoint of the range stated by Johnson would be equivalent to a decline of 13 percent.

In response to a question about future repurchases of common stock, Johnson told the group that if Fannie Mae management believed the opportunities were right for a buyback, it would not hesitate to go the board and seek authorization.
In connection with a capital restructuring, Fannie Mae has issued $1 billion of preferred stock this year and repurchased 48 million common shares.

Johnson said when he spoke to the same group in 1994 he committed Fannie Mae to achieving double-digit annual earnings growth, $1 trillion in targeted lending to U.S. families in need of help, industry leadership and building its franchise.

Johnson said Fannie Mae had met all four of the commitments and was making a new one -- that earnings will show a healthy rate of growth relative to Fannie Mae's peers, and with a high rate of predictability.

He said "peers" were selected by asking the biggest institutional holders of Fannie Mae to identify their other big holdings. These included such companies as General Electric Co and Merck & Co Inc, he said.
According to a chart comparing Fannie Mae to 10 peers, Fannie Mae had higher-than-average five-year historic and five-year predicted growth rates, with less volatility.
